article:
The 'cinema of Pakistan' refers to Pakistan's film industry. Most of the feature
films shot in Pakistan are in Urdu language but may also include films in
English, Punjabi, Pashto, Balochi or Sindhi languages. Pakistan's largest film
industry is Lollywood.

Before the separation of Bangladesh, Pakistan had three main film production
centres: Lahore, Karachi and Dhaka. Dhaka was lost after 1971. The regime of
Muhammad Zia-ul-Haq, VCRs, film piracy, the introduction of entertainment taxes,
and Islamic laws, have been some of the many obstacles to the industry's growth.
Once thriving, the cinema in Pakistan now barely
exists. [http://www.bollywhat.com/beyond/pakistani.html The Beginner's Guide
to Pakistani Cinema]

The Pakistani film industry is credited with having produced some of the most
notable and recognised filmmakers, actors, writers and directors, and for
introducing pop music to South Asia and beyond. Ahmed
Rushdi.http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ahmed_Rushdi Competition from
Bollywood and piracy, however, have led to the industry's decline.
